document.text: Stuart Farrar, of Pamplin, happened upon a shelf of Lyn chburg directories among the records in the court house, Ly nchburg. In the oldest directory there, 1887-1888 he found sev eral pages of interesting in formation about this county back when  Rose Bower ,  Neb raska ,  Reedy Springs etc. were post office locations.  Ne-  braska , of course was the pre sent county seat,the Town of Appomattox. Population in 1887 was 10,080 with 5,153 white and 4,927 colored. County seat was  listed as Appomattox CH the  old village, now Appom attox j Court House National Historical j Park with a population of 100.  Average assessed value of j lands in 1887-1888 was 4.13 j per acre. The Circuit Court of I the Fifth Circuit met on the 15th  of March and 15th of Sept, with  Judge John D. Horsley and Geo rge T. Peers as clerk. Henry T. Parish was county judge and Mr. Peers serving as clerk and County Court met at the Court House Thursday after the 1st Monday in each month. County officers 84 years ago were T. B. Bryant, sheriff A.S. j Swan, surveyor, J . R. Franklin, Treasurer George W. Abbitt, commissioner of the revenue and W. C. Franklin, common wealths attorney. The supervisor board, then as now, was composed of three representatives, one from each district Wm. White was chair man together with D. H. Mar shall and H. E . Gilliam. County magistrates were A. Womack, C . H. Gilliam, Pam plin City Ja s. A. Walker, Tower Hill N. W. Owen, Oakville C. W. Cardwell, Spout Spring C.B .

A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. McGavock, of Max Meadows, a frtaster of arts of the Lynch burg Randolph-Macon Womans College and a bachelor of philosophy of the Uni versity of Chicago, will have chargei of the chair of mathematics and science in Sullins College, Bristol, next year. Col. Robert A. Marr, professor of en gineering at the Virginia Military Insti tute, at Lexington, has resigned to go to the Virginia Polytechnic Institute, at Blacksburg. It was ascertained in Lynchburg on good authority that the impending re- port of the Southern Railways business for the fiscal year ended June 30 will be one of the most remarkable annual re ports ever made by a railroad in the South. The year has been the best the system has ever enjoyed, and the in crease in revenues is said to make a wonderful showing. The report is tc be issued in the next few days. The corner-stone o the elaborate monument to be erected in Richmond to Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederacy, will be laid November 8 with simple ceremonies. It is proposed to unveil the monument June 3, 1907, the ninety-ninth anniversary of the birth of Mr. Davis. The contract for the purchase of the real estate necessary as a site for the memorial was closed. The memorial will be located at the intersec tion of Cedar and Franklin streets, and is to be surrounded hy a circle with a radius sufficient to afford an environ ment in keeping with the massive and handsome design. document.text: Unique plans for providing for James town Exposition visitors were presented at Norfolk. One calls for a hotel at Se wells Point that will be built like a large steamer with accommodations for upward of 500 persons. The other plan calls for a hotel to be erected over the water to be connected with the shore by a large j pier. The plan provides for a steamer I landing directly at the hotel pier. President Harry St. George Tucker, of Ihe Jamestown Exposition Company, is in Washington conferring with the Secre- lary of War, the Navy and the Treasury, who are to lact as the representatives of ihe Government in the arrangement of the exhibits and for the expenditure of the money. He is preparing passports and credentials also for a trip to Europe in the interest of the celebration. The Farmville and Powhatan railroad has been purchased by the Tidewater nd Western and the telegraph lines i thing the road have come undeT the con tri 1 of the Postal Company. The United States Leather Company, which recently purchased the tannery at Moorefield of Cover  Drayton, is ar ranging to spend 50,000 in improve ments. The company will install its own. lighting plant and will also light the town of Moorefield. Large sums will probably he spent on improvements at the tanner ies at Narrows, Giles County, Va., Lost City and Capon Bridge. Dr. William H. Taylor, State chemist ind coroner, stated that the deaths of doth the children of Mrs. Edward Per rins were caused by phosphorous poison ing. This statement was made after care ful and scientific analysis of the stomachs of the two children, William, aged 2, and Octavia, aged 5. The coroner did not itate his belief that the children were murdered, but those present drew their awn conclusions, and their belief is that the poison was administered by some one ret unknown. The -trial is before a jury Df six, and the coroners statement con- terning the case was intensely interesting. Levi T. F. Grim, 86 years old, died at bis home in Winchester. Mr. Grim was born in Washington County, Md., and came to Winchester with his father, the late Samuel Grim, when 16 years old. For many years he was hotel-keeper here, having been the proprietor of Grims tav ern, famed all over Virginia a decade ago. He served two terms as treasurer of Winchester, and was for several years a member of the city council. Mr. Grim leaves three daughters Mrs. George Haymaker and Mrs. A. M. Zirkle, of Winchester, and Mrs. John Shearer, of Philadelphia and four sons Lee R. Grim, cashier of the Union Bank William E., Thomas F. and Frank L. Grim, all of Winchester. James McCormick, a io-year-old boy, abtained a verdict in the Court of Law ind Chancery, Norfolk, against the Nor folk and Atlantic Terminal Railway Company for 10,000. He was thrown or fell from a car on July 4 coming from Pine Beach. His right leg and two fin gers of his right hand were cut off by the wheels of the car. He was picked up unconscious and supposed to be dead, but recovered at the hospital. He uses two crutches now. Attorneys for the railway moved for a new trial. The police of Manchester think they have in Bob Pusick, whom they have arrested, the Captain Kidd of the So ciety of Yachting Pirates, charged with looting summer estates, clubhouses, etc., an Long Island Sound. Pusick gives his occupation as automobile and1 motorboat repairer. The police believe he is Jack- son, leader of the gang, who is supposed to have fled South. The faculty and literary societies of the University of Virginia have invited Secretary Root to deliver an address at the universary on February 22. Presi dent Alderman has gone to Washington to carry the invitation. The Virginia Daughters of the Amer ican Revolution assembled at Roanoke in ninth annual convention, with 50 dele gates present, representing all sections of the state. Mrs. Eleanor S. Washing ton Howard, of Alexandria, state regent, presided, and read her annual report, which showed gratifying gains. There have been three new chapters organized during the last year and 97 new mem bers added. Mrs. Hartón, wife of William D. Har tón, of Richmond, surprised a burglar in her chamber on an upper floor of the house, and put him to fight. Mrs. Har tón was entertaining several lady friends in the sitting room, and hearing a stealthy tread overhead, went to inves tigate. The man declared that he had been sent upstairs by a gentleman to get a shirt. Knowing that there was no man in the house, Mrs. Hartón recog nized that she had to deal with a bur glar, and picking up a broom she hurled it -at the man and at the same time screamed for help. The burglar made his escape through the back door. Considerable interest was manifested in the annual meeting of the stockhold ers of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway at Richmond under the belief that ac tion would be taken increasing divi dends. The question did not come up, however, and the only business trans acted was the re-election of the old board of directors. Chauncey M. Depew Is among -the number. J. C. Ctitchin, of Franklin, was ar rested there on the charge of swindling merchants of Norfolk to the extent of 1,100 by forged checks on the bank in Franklin in the name of his uncle, C. J. Cutchin. He bought jewelry and other articles, it is charged, and sent them to a confederate there. The first checks he gave were paid because the bank did not detect the supposed forgery. The Old Dominion Boat Club, of Alexandria, has arranged for the en largement and remodeling of its boat house. James Pruitt, the 14-year-old son. of John C. Pruitt, of Danville, fell beneath ihe wheels of a moving train in the vicinity of the Riverside Cotton Mills, ind was killed. Young Pruitt and some ither boys were riding on cars being moved from the yard hy a shifting en gine, when he struck a post at the gate o the cotton mill yards and was thrown under the wheels. The body was man gled and death was instantaneous. The ody was viewed by a coroners! jury, ju-t no verdict has yet been rendered. Morris, of Leesburg, ías been called to the redórate of Christ Church, Norfolk, recently left by Rev. Carl C. Grammernow of Philadelphia, ind will likely accept. The salary is 3.000 and manse. The Alexandria Water Company has laid a 12-inch main from its works at Mount Cameron to the new depot to supply water for the railroads. Mr. Julian W. Robey, of Staffer! county, fell from the gable roof of  second-story dwelling, on which he wa working, but escaped serious injury. Hi was badly bruised, but no bones wen broken.

document.text: AlteT serving as local Postmaster tor twenty-two and one-half years E. LeRoy Smith will retire on Jan uary 1, 1.957, after reaching the re quired age for retirement on De cember 26k On. June 1, 1934, Mr, Smith was appointed Acting Postmaster by the late President Franklin D. Roose velt, who later made the permanent appointment. Mr. Smith succeeded- ed J, E. Dinwiddle. A t that time Appomattox was a third class office with annual postal receipts totalling 7,411.19. In 1936 the office was advanced to second class. As a result of large parcel post shipments made by local Garment Companies, the postal re ceipt mounted to 41,504.94 in 1950, which advanced the office fur ther to first class. Postal receipts in 1955 were -53,946.00. In 1947 toe Post Office building was enlarged and remodeled to adequately take care of the grow ing business. Mrs. Rachel F. Lawson came in the Post Office as clerk at the time of Mr. Smdfths appointment, and still holds this position. Other dorks now are John T. Hall and H W. Billy Conner. The R. F. D. carriers serving at the time o f Mx. Smdithi appointment were Judson S. Kinney and Luther J. Morris, and toe Date J. Kline Pulliam, Thomas E. LeGrand. The present carriers are W. E. Han cock, William C. Hubbard, Reggie W. Stanley and S. A. Lawaon. Mr. Smith has been an untiring worker during has term of office, being one of the first to report to work at 6 oclock Af M., seven days A week, and the last to leave in the evening. During hie tenure of office he possibly breaks a national re cord, having used only 10 days annual leave and pat a single day of sick leave.. His record shows 2,454 bourn of unused annual leave! Mr. .Smith came to Appomattox County in 1907 when hie late par ents, Mr. and Mrs. M. C. Smito, bought Mammoth Oak Farm and moved here with their family from Washington County, feferyiand. Mr. Snuthe find pim tioi after moving here wae that of a teach er in the LeGrand School. He walked four miles daily to and from school, and received a salary of 20.00 per month. He wae later interested in a number of enter prises in the county, among them toe mercantile busineas. He served as a member of the Appomattox County School Board for 15 years. He is affiliated with toe Monroe Mia- eonic Lodge and has been active in the Appomattox Memorial ,Metho dist Church. He is at present church treasurer and a member of the Board of Stewards. He married the former Miss Adjie Pace, o f Haikfex County, and they are the parents of one son, L. Pace Smith, of JWls Church three daughters, Mm E. N. Brown, of Rockville, Md., and Mrs. Charlie J. Hunter and Mm Jhrnee R. Red ding, of this place, The personnel of toe local Post Office plans a dinner honoring Mr. and Mm Smith on December 28. The dimmer will be held at the Ap pomattox Hotel, and will be attend ed by representative of the Post Office Department from the Roanoke and Lynchburg offices. By M m J. R, Lawson.

document.text: After several years of litigation the noted Suit of W alter Bird, of London, England, vs. Major StepHen P. Halsey, a prominent tobacconist of Lynchburg, was finally disposed of. In the original trial in the United States Circuit Court the jurys decision was in favor of Mr. Bird. The lower court, however, was reversed by the Circuit Court of A p peals, and when the case was taken up in the United States District Court,M r. Birds counsel stated that he did not de sire to prosecute the case further, as he was unable to give the security. Judge Paul accordingly dismissed the suit, or dering that the plaintiff pay defend ants costs. Floyd Eaton, the young-son of Mr. William Eaton, of Capon Bridge, was shot, and perhaps fatally, by Lap John son. The latter was riding along the road, and he saw some object running along beneath some trees a considerable distance, ahead of him. He thought the object was a dog and fired with a dou ble-barreled shotgun. The object prov ed to be young Eaton, and the entire load struck him in the back. The wounded lad was carried by Johnson to his fathers home and a physician sum moned. His injuries are serious and perhaps fatal. Johnson was not arrest ed, as the affair was clearly an accident. A special term of the Circuit Court of Clarke County has been called to convene on March 27. This term will be presided over by Judge C. E. Nicol, of the Eleventh Judicial Circuit. It is called to hear the boom cases of the Berryville Land and Improvement Co. against delinquent stockholders, who are resisting payment of assessment on the stock of that company, which went into the hands of a receiver some years back. There are no cases now pending on the docket of this court in which so much feeling has been engendered and which are as hotly contested as these cases. The farmers institute of Shenandoah county was held in the court house at W oodstock and was the most success ful and interesting one ever held there. The program included addresses by Hon. Martin Dodge, of the United States Road Commission Professor A 1 vord, of the Dairy Division, Depart ment of Agriculture Prof. Frank F. Rogers, of Port Huron, Mich., and Mr. John W . Copp, of Fishers HilL Va. Essays were read by Messrs. Ernest Funk, Frank Richards and others. A large nnmber of farmers attended the institute and pronounce it the best ever held. The annuaL stockholders meeting of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company was held in the of fice of General Superintendent W . A. Post, at the shipyard, with about all of the shares represented. C. B. Orcutt was unanimously re-elected president of the company for the ensuing year, and I. E. Gates was unanimously re elected treasurer. The following di rectors were elected C. B. Orcutt, New Y ork Charles H. Tweed, New York H. E. Huntington, New York I. E. Gates, New Y ork F. H. Davis, New York. A charter has been granted in the CircuitCourt at Lexington by Judge S. H. Letcher to the Rockbridge White Sulphur Springs Company for the pur pose of operating arid improving the property known as the McCIuers Springs property, situated about eight miles southwest of Lexington. The capital stock is not to be less than 1000 and the shares 100 each. The land limi tations are 100 acres. The property is expected to be improved and made a summer resort. Peter Light, a well-known farmer of L og Marsh district, Clarke County, died suddenly from heart trouble. Mr. Light retired as usual after eating a very hearty meal, and some time during the night he awakened his wife and told her he was very unwell. Mrs. Light left the room to rouse her soil, rind when she returned her husband was unconscious, and death ensued in ten minutes. The deceased was 76 years old and leaves a widow and nine grown children. Mr. A . de Costa, of New York, for merly of Spain, with other capitalists, has leased the Rappahannock gold mine in Stafford county, about ten miles above Fredericksburg,and after intro ducing improved machinery will begin active mining operation. The mine has been leased for three years, with the privilege of purchasing. Mr. de Costa, with his family, will reside at the mine. The Board of Supervisors of Rock bridge has appointed a committee to look into the affairs of the Valley Rail road to examine the books so far as practicable and all other matters per tinent to the road relative to the county and report to the board, making such suggestions as deemed advisable. The county holds stock in the road to the face value of 420,000 hence this move. The suit which Hugh Gordon Milier, United States District Attorney, insti tuted recently against Sylvanus Stokes, proprietor of the Monticello Hotel, has been adjusted in a manner satisfactory to both parties. Mr. Miller claimed damages to the extent of 25,000 be cause of remarks and allegations which Mr. Stokes is alleged to have made. Samuel Maness, aged 23, was shot and killed near Fairview, Scott county, by E. Garland. Maness was out with a hunting party. For same cause Gar land fired upon the party as they were passing by his home. Gen. Scott Shipp, superintendent ot the Virginia Military Institute, has as his guest Capt. Louis B. Lawton, of the Ninth United States Infgntry, who was wounded severely at the battle of Tientsin, China, last summer and later promoted tor his great gallantry during that action. Boland Holmes and Martha Beach were convicted at Williamsburg of the joint murder of James Beach and given 18 years each. They murdered Beach, the womans husband, and carried his body several miles up a creek and placed it on the railroad track, to indi cate accidental death. Mr. John S. Bethel, Collector of Cus toms at Richmond, is dead. The de ceased was a staunch Republican and had figured prominently in public af fairs. H e was a self-made man. In ac cordance with his dying reauest the Amreican flag will be placed on his coffin. A house owned by Mr. Jonas Barrett, at Cedar Grove, was -destroyed _ by a fire believed to be the work of incen diaries. Until recently the house had been tenanted, but was unoccupied at the time of the fire. Coal oil was sprinkled over the entire honse when the fire was discovered by neighboro. it is estimated that 500 people have left Franklin county within the past xear in search of homes in Hie West.
